children.subject: It's definitely possible, but do be prepared for a lot of work, especially with Hilfinger's 61B projects. It will also definitely be helpful if you've been exposed to the concepts in multivariable calc and AP Physics C before.

Personally, I would not recommend this for your first ever semester. Try to go a little easier first semester just so you can figure out a good pace for yourself and adjust to college life as well. I would say stick with 2 techs max 3 if you really want and take either a breadth, seminar, or decal.

Same as Anon Comp. I wouldn't recommend this.

Having taken 3/4 of those classes personally, the workload would roughly breakdown outside of lectures and discussion to:

16A: weekly problem sets that take 3-9 hours a week, depending on how good your linear algebra and circuits knowledge is

61B: 3-10 hours a week, but quickly picks up when there are projects around. You could spend up to anywhere from 10-40 hours on the projects. 

Math 53: there's no required weekly homework, but you'll want to prepare for weekly quizzes which means doing practice problems for maybe an 1-2 hours a day.

Physics 7A: Haven't taken, but I imagine weekly problem sets which could align with 16A.

You'll definitely want to ease into your first semester and explore things outside of schoolwork, so maybe take 3 of those classes plus a decal or light breadth. Hope this helps :)

history.content: Four tech is too much from my perspective. I took three techs in one semester and it was busy. CS 61B with hug has fair workload but you need to carefully prepare for the difficult exam. EECS 16A is not easy, especially if you do not have linear algebra and circuit background. I spend more time on 16A than on 16B. Math 53 is difficult, but it varies from person to person. For me math 53 is even harder than all 5 core upper division math courses. I cannot comment on 7A because I get a 5 on AP physic C mechanics.

children.subject: I won’t stop you from doing that because you should be able to figure out whether 4 technicals is too much after the first two weeks. You can always drop classes before the 5th week. I actually think these 4 technicals have reasonable workload, but this depends on your strength. For example, 16A and math 53 for me is quite easy (each 3 hours a week outside the class), but 61b is sometimes conceptually hard. Physics 7A/B generally have low workload but they are definitely more in depth than AP physics C. Other people will have different opinions, which all depend on personal interests, past experience, specific professors. It’s better for you to experience the workload yourself before making the decision.

history.content: Hi, I had a question: Will taking Math 53 and Physics 7A be too much to handle together, along with 61B and 16A for a freshman semester 1?
history.subject: 61B+16A+Math 53+Physics 7A Freshman Course Rigor?
